text: In The Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less, Barry Schwartz explores how sensory experiences influence decision-making. He describes an experiment in which shoppers were asked to sample pieces of chocolate. One group was allowed to hold and smell the chocolate before tasting, while the other group only tasted it without any prior interaction. Participants who were allowed to engage their senses more thoroughly reported greater enjoyment and were willing to pay more for the product. Schwartz argues that the physical interaction with the product increased its perceived value. This finding suggests that ______.
question: Which choice most logically completes the text?
A: sensory interaction with a product can enhance its perceived value to consumers.
B: consumers who rely on taste alone are less likely to buy premium-quality products.
C: retailers should avoid offering free samples, as they reduce the exclusivity of products.
D: shoppers prefer products they have not physically interacted with to maintain objectivity.
explanation:
Choice A is the best answer. The experiment demonstrates that physical interaction heightened participants’ perception of value and enjoyment, aligning with Schwartz’s argument.Choice B is incorrect. The passage does not suggest that taste alone makes consumers less likely to choose premium products.Choice C is incorrect. The text implies that free samples positively influence perception and does not discourage their use.Choice D is incorrect. The text suggests the opposite—that physical interaction increases appeal rather than reducing objectivity.
